name: Burpee
description: Begin standing, then squat down and place hands on floor, kick feet back to a plank position, perform a push-up, jump feet back to hands, and explosively jump up with arms overhead.
formTips: Maintain a strong core throughout the entire movement
Land softly with knees slightly bent after jumping
Keep shoulders stacked over wrists in plank position
Control your descent in the push-up portion
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the plank/push-up
Not performing a full range of motion
Landing with straight legs on the jump
benefits: Elevates heart rate for cardiovascular conditioning
Builds full-body strength and power
Burns significant calories in short time periods
Improves coordination and agility
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower to squat, exhale during the push-up, inhale as you jump feet forward, exhale during the jump
preparationSteps: Start in a standing position with feet shoulder-width apart
Ensure you have enough space around you
Keep your core engaged throughout the movement
Prepare mentally for an intense exercise

name: Mountain Climber
description: Begin in a plank position with hands under shoulders. Rapidly alternate bringing knees toward chest in a running motion while maintaining a stable upper body.
formTips: Keep hips level and in line with shoulders (avoid piking)
Drive knees forward with control and speed
Maintain a strong plank position throughout
Keep shoulders stacked over wrists
commonMistakes: Not bringing knees far enough forward
Moving too slowly to elevate heart rate
progressionExercises: mountain climber with cross-body knee drive
regressionExercises: incline mountain climber on bench or wall
benefits: Combines strength training with cardiovascular benefit
Strengthens core while improving hip mobility
Burns calories and increases heart rate efficiently
Develops coordination and agility
breathingPattern: Breathe rhythmically with movement; avoid holding breath
preparationSteps: Start in a high plank position with hands directly under shoulders
Set feet hip-width apart
Engage core and establish a stable position
Look slightly ahead to maintain neutral neck alignment

name: Push-Up
description: Begin in a high plank position with hands slightly wider than shoulders. Lower your body until chest nearly touches the floor, then push back up to the starting position.
formTips: Keep body in a straight line from head to heels
Position hands slightly wider than shoulder-width
Lower until chest is about an inch from the floor
Keep elbows at roughly a 45-degree angle from body
commonMistakes: Sagging or piking at the hips
Not lowering far enough or going too deep
benefits: Builds upper body strength and muscular endurance
Strengthens core and stabilizer muscles
Improves posture and shoulder stability
Can be done anywhere with no equipment
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower, exhale as you push up
preparationSteps: Start in a high plank position with hands slightly wider than shoulders
Set feet together or hip-width apart for stability
Engage core and glutes to maintain a straight body line
Position gaze slightly ahead of hands for neutral neck alignment

name: Box Push-Up
description: A modified push-up performed from a box position (hands and knees) with knees on the ground. Lower chest toward the floor by bending elbows, then push back up.
formTips: Align hands directly under shoulders
Keep back flat and core engaged
Lower until chest is 1-2 inches from floor
Fully extend arms at the top without locking elbows
commonMistakes: Letting hips sag during the movement
benefits: Builds upper body strength with reduced load
Prepares for standard push-ups
Develops chest, shoulder and tricep strength
Ideal for beginners or those with limited upper body strength
contraindications: Wrist pain or carpal tunnel syndrome
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower, exhale as you push up
preparationSteps: Start on hands and knees in a box position
Place hands directly beneath shoulders, slightly wider than shoulder-width
Keep knees under hips at 90-degree angles
Engage core to stabilize the spine before beginning

name: Knee Push-Up
description: A modified push-up performed with knees on the ground and ankles crossed. Lower chest toward the floor by bending elbows, then push back up while maintaining a straight line from head to knees.
formTips: Keep body in a straight line from head to knees
Position hands slightly wider than shoulders
Lower until chest nearly touches the floor
Keep elbows at about 45 degrees from body
commonMistakes: Sagging or piking at the hips
Placing hands too far forward or outward
benefits: Builds upper body strength with reduced loading
Helps develop proper push-up form
Strengthens chest, shoulders, and triceps
Improves core stability
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower your body, exhale as you push back up
preparationSteps: Kneel on an exercise mat for comfort
Place hands on the floor slightly wider than shoulders
Cross ankles and lift feet off the ground
Engage core to maintain a straight line from head to knees

name: Superman
description: Lie face down with arms extended overhead. Simultaneously lift arms, chest, and legs off the floor, hold briefly, then lower back down with control.
formTips: Engage core before lifting limbs
Lift arms and legs to a comfortable height (a few inches is sufficient)
Keep neck in a neutral position, looking at the floor
Focus on lengthening through fingertips and toes
commonMistakes: Hyperextending the neck (looking up too much)
Lifting too high causing lower back strain
benefits: Strengthens the entire posterior chain
Improves posture and counters effects of sitting
Stabilizes the spine and core
Helps alleviate lower back pain when done correctly
contraindications: Severe lower back pain or injury
breathingPattern: Inhale as you prepare, exhale as you lift, breathe normally during the hold, inhale as you lower
preparationSteps: Lie face down on a mat with arms extended overhead
Position legs straight and together
Place forehead on the mat for neutral neck alignment
Engage your core gently before beginning the movement

name: Swimmer and Superman
description: A combination exercise where you alternate between the superman position (all limbs lifted) and a swimming motion where opposite arm and leg lower while the others remain elevated.
formTips: Maintain core engagement throughout
Keep movements controlled and rhythmic
Lift only as high as comfortable without strain
Focus on the contraction in your back muscles
regressionExercises: prone upper or lower body lifts only
benefits: Develops coordination while strengthening the back
Improves muscular endurance in posterior chain
Enhances spinal stability and core function
Helps counteract effects of prolonged sitting
contraindications: Acute lower back pain or injury
breathingPattern: Establish a rhythm with your movements - typically inhale during one phase and exhale during the other
preparationSteps: Lie face down on a mat with arms extended overhead
Position legs straight and together
Engage your core gently to support your spine
Start with a full superman position (all limbs lifted)

name: Bird Dog
description: Start on hands and knees. Simultaneously extend one arm forward and the opposite leg back while maintaining a stable core. Return to starting position and repeat with opposite limbs.
formTips: Keep hips and shoulders square to the floor throughout
Extend arm and leg fully without overarching back
Maintain a neutral spine and engaged core
Move with control rather than speed
commonMistakes: Rotating hips or shoulders during extension
Lifting arm or leg too high
Moving too quickly and losing stability
progressionExercises: bird dog with elbow to knee
regressionExercises: single limb raises (arm or leg only)
benefits: Improves core stability and balance
Strengthens back and hip extensors simultaneously
Enhances coordination between upper and lower body
Promotes proper spinal alignment
breathingPattern: Inhale as you prepare, exhale as you extend limbs, inhale as you return to starting position
preparationSteps: Start on hands and knees in tabletop position
Place hands directly under shoulders and knees under hips
Keep back flat (neutral spine) and head in line with spine
Engage your core by drawing navel toward spine

name: One Leg Push-Up
description: A challenging push-up variation where one leg is lifted off the ground, increasing the core stability demands while performing a standard push-up.
formTips: Maintain a straight body line from head to extended foot
Keep hips square to the floor (avoid rotation)
Engage core strongly throughout the movement
Perform full range of motion push-up while balancing
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to rotate or sag
Shortening the push-up range of motion
benefits: Increases core and hip stability demands
Builds unilateral strength and balance
Enhances body awareness and coordination
Adds challenge to standard push-up training
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower, exhale as you push up
preparationSteps: Begin in a standard push-up position with hands under shoulders
Engage your core firmly
Lift one leg a few inches off the ground
Ensure hips are level before beginning the push-up motion
